provisions.title: Section 42
provisions.content:
42. Where blasts are fired from power circnits-
    (a) safety switches located at safe distances from the blast areas
        shall be provided in addition to the main blasting switch;
    (b) blasting switches shall be locked in the open position except
        when closed to fire the blast. Lead wires shall not be connected
        to the blasting switch until the shot is ready to be fired;
    (c) electric circuits from the blasting switches to the blast area
         shall not be grounded,;
    (d) power sources shall be suitable for the number of electric
        detonators to be fired and for the type of circuits used;
    (e) if any part of a blast is connected in parallel the time of
        current flow shall be limited to 25 milliseconds by incorporating
         a control device in the blasting circuit or by interrupting the
         circuit with a zero-delay electric blasting cap attached to one
         or both lead lines.

provisions.title: Section 63
provisions.content:
63. When a drill is being moved from one drilling area to another.
drill steel, tools and other equipment shall be secured and the mast
p!aced in a safe position.

provisions.title: Section 64
provisions.content:
64. The drill helper, when used, shall be in sight of the operator
at all times while the drill is being moved to a new location.

provisions.title: Section 65
provisions.content:
65. In the event of power failure, drill controls shall be placed in
the neutral position until power is restored.

provisions.title: Section 66
provisions.content:
66. Before attempts are made to straighten a crossed cable on a
reel, the drill stem shall be resting on the bottom of the hole or on
the platform with the stem secured to the mast.

provisions.title: Section 68
provisions.content:
68. Drill holes large enough to constitute a hazard shall be covered
or guarded.

provisions.title: Section 69
provisions.content:
69. Employees operating or working near jackhammers or jackleg
drills and other drilling machines shall position themselves so that
they will not be struck or lose their balance if the drill steel breaks
or sticks.

provisions.title: Section 70
provisions.content:
70. Employees shall not drill from positions that hinder their access
 to the control levers, or from insecure footing or staging, or from
 atop equipment not designed for this pwose.

provisions.title: Section 72
provisions.content:
72. Employees shall not hold the dhll steel while collaring holes
 or rest their hands on the chuck or centralizer while drilling.

provisions.title: Section 73
provisions.content:
73. Air shall be turned off and bled from the hose before handheld
 drills are moved from one working area to another.

provisions.title: Section 74
provisions.content:
74. Holes shall not be drilled where there is danger of intersecting
 a charged or misfired hole and no person shall drill within two feet
 of any hole or remnant of a hole that has been charged and blasted.

provisions.title: Section 75
provisions.content:
75. No person shall drill within five feet of any hole containing
     explosives.
                   PARTIV. Loading, Hauling and Dumping

provisions.title: Section 76
provisions.content:
76. Materials shall be stockpiled at a height and slope consistent
     with their natural angle of repose and the reclaiming equipment to
     be used.

provisions.title: Section 78
provisions.content:
78. Dumping locations and haulage roads shall be kept reasonably
     free of water, debris, and spillage.

provisions.title: Section 79
provisions.content:
79. Berms, bumper blocks, safety hooks, or similar means shall be
     provided to prevent overtravel and overturning at dumping locations.

provisions.title: Section 80
provisions.content:
80. Grizzlies, grates, and other sizing devices at dump and transfer
     points shall be anchored securely in place.

provisions.title: Section 81
provisions.content:
81. Where overhead clearance is restricted, warning devices shall be
     installed and the restricted area shall be conspicuously marked.

provisions.title: Section 82
provisions.content:
82. Only authorized persons shall be present in areas of loading or
     dumping operations.

provisions.title: Section 83
provisions.content:
83. Powered mobile haulage equipment shall be provided with audible
     warning devices. Lights shall be provided on both ends.

provisions.title: Section 84
provisions.content:
84. No vehicle having an obstructed view to the rear shall be backed
     unless it is equipped withaan automatic, audible, back-up warning
     device or unless an observe^ is used to direct the operator in rearward
     movement.

provisions.title: Section 85
provisions.content:
85. Operators shall be certain by signal or other means, that all
     persons are clear before starting or moving equipment.

provisions.title: Section 86
provisions.content:
86. When an operator is present men shall notify him before getting
     on or off equipment.

provisions.title: Section 87
provisions.content:
87. Lights, flares, or other warning devices shall be posted when
     parked equipment creates a hazard to vehicular traffic.

provisions.title: Section 88
provisions.content:
88. Operators shall sit facing the direction of travel while operating
     equipment with dual controls.

provisions.title: Section 89
provisions.content:
89. Men shall not work or pass under the buckets or booms of
loaders in operation.

provisions.title: Section 90
provisions.content:
90. Where truck spotters are used, they shall be well in the clear
while trucks are backing into dumping position and dumping. Lights
shall be used at nights to direct trucks where the lighting in the area
is inadequate.

provisions.title: Section 91
provisions.content:
91. Electrically powered mobile equipanent shall not be I& un-
attended unless the master switch is in the off position, all operating
controls are in the neutral position, and the brakes are set or other
equivalent precautions are taken against rolling.

provisions.title: Section 92
provisions.content:
92. Trucks, shuttle cars, and front-end loaders shall be equipped
with emergency brakes separate and independent of the regular braking
system.

provisions.title: Section 93
provisions.content:
93. A tow bar shall be used to tow heavy equi,pment. A safety chain
shall be used in conjunction wi.th the tow bar.

provisions.title: Section 94
provisions.content:
94. Any load extending more than 1.25 metres (4 ft.) beyond the
rear of the vehicle body shall be marked clearly with a red flag by
day and a red light by night.

provisions.title: Section 95
provisions.content:
95. Operators' cabs shall be constructed to permit operators to see
without straining and shall1 be reasonably comfortable.

provisions.title: Section 96
provisions.content:
96. Cab windows shall be d safety glass or equivalent, in good
condition and shall be kept clean.

provisions.title: Section 100
provisions.content:
100. Mobile equipment operators shall have full control of the equip-
 ment while it is in motion.
                [me inclwion of this page is authorized by L.N. 71119791
    THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 101
provisions.content:
101. Dippers, buckets, loading booms, or heavy suspended loads
shall not be swung over the cabs of haulage vehicles until the drivers
are out of them and in safe locations, unless the vehicles are designed
specifically to protect the drivers from falling materials of the types
involved.

provisions.title: Section 102
provisions.content:
102. Equipment operating speeds shall be prudent and consistent with
conditions of roadway, grades, clearance, visibility. traflic, and the
type of equipment used.

provisions.title: Section 103
provisions.content:
103. Vehicles shall follow each other at a safe distance; passing
should be limited to areas of adequate clearance and visibility.

provisions.title: Section 104
provisions.content:
104. Dust control measures shall be taken where dust significantlg
reduces visibility of equipment operators.

provisions.title: Section 105
provisions.content:
105. Traffic rules, signals, and warning signs shall be standardized
and posted.

provisions.title: Section 106
provisions.content:
106. Men shall not work on or from a piece of mobile equipment
in a hoisted position until it has been blocked in place securely. This
does not preclude the use of equipment specifically designed as elevated
mobile work platforms.

provisions.title: Section 107
Section 108
provisions.content:
108. Dippers, buckets, scraper blades, and similar movable parts
shall be secured or lowered to the ground when not in use.

provisions.title: Section 109
provisions.content:
109. When travelling between work areas, the equipment shall be
secured in the travel position.

provisions.title: Section 110
provisions.content:
110. Equipment which is to be hauled shall be loaded and pmtected
so as to prevent sliding or spillage.

provisions.title: Section 111
provisions.content:
111. Repairs or maintenance shall not be performd on machinery
unless the motive power is off and the machinery is blocked against
     THE MINING (SAFETY A N D HEALTH) REGULATIONS. 1977
motion, except where machinery motion is necessary to make adjust-
ments.

provisions.title: Section 112
provisions.content:
112. Mobile equipment shall not be left unattended unless the brakes
are set. The wheels shall be turned into a bank or rib, or shall be
blocked. when parked on a grade.

provisions.title: Section 113
provisions.content:
113. Cars or trucks shall be loaded in such a manner as to minimize
spillage while en route to a dumping site.

provisions.title: Section 114
provisions.content:
114. Adequate protection shall be provided against falling materials
where such hazards exist.

provisions.title: Section 115
provisions.content:
115. Men shall not-
    (a) get on or off    moving equipment, except that trainmen may
         get on or off slowly-moving trains;
    (6) ride between cars or on top of closed or loaded cars.

provisions.title: Section 116
provisions.content:
116. Only authorized persons shall be permitted to ride on trains
or locomotives and they shall ride in a safe position.

provisions.title: Section 117
provisions.content:
117. Rocker-bottom or bottom-dump cars shall be equipped with
positive locking devices.

provisions.title: Section 118
provisions.content:
118. Chute-loading instatallations shall be designed so that the men
pulling chutes are not nquired to be in a hazardous posi,tion while
loading cars.

provisions.title: Section 119
provisions.content:
119. Positive-acting stoplocks, derail devices, track skates, or other
adequate means shall be installed wherever necessary to protect persons
from runaway or moving railroad equipment.

provisions.title: Section 120
provisions.content:
120. Switch throws shall be installed so as to provide adequate
clearance for switchmen.

provisions.title: Section 122
provisions.content:
122. Movements of two or more pieces of rail equipment operating
independently on the same track shall be regulated by an efficient
signal block, telephone, or radio system; movements on complex
haulage systems shall be effectively controlled.

provisions.title: Section 123
provisions.content:
123. Parked railcars, unless held effectively by brakes, shall be
blocked securely.

provisions.title: Section 124
provisions.content:
124. Persons shall not go over, under, or between rail cars as a
means of crossing, unless the train is stopped and the motorman
has been notified, and the notice acknowledged.

provisions.title: Section 125
provisions.content:
125. Inability of the motorman to clearly recognize his brakeman's
signals when the train is under the direction of the brakeman, shall
be construed by the motoman as a stop signal.

provisions.title: Section 127
provisions.content:
127. Public and permanent railroad crossings shall be posted with
warning signs and signals, or shall be guarded when trains are passing
and shall be planked or otherwise filled between the rails.

provisions.title: Section 128
provisions.content:
128. Roadbeds, rails, joints, switches, frogs and other elements on
railroads shall be designed, installed and maintained in a safe manner
consistent with the speed and type of haulage.

provisions.title: Section 129
provisions.content:
129. Track guardrails, lead rails, and frogs shall be protected or
blocked as to prevent a person's foot from becoming wedged therein.
where such openings occur in a walkway crossing tracks.

provisions.title: Section 130
provisions.content:
130.--(1) Trains shall be brought to a complete stop when carrying
out the manual aspects of the coupling or uncoupling of cars.
       (2) Persons coupling or uncoupling cars shall be within sight
of the motorman or a third person shall act as co-ordiqating signal-
man.
        (3) Makeshift couplings shall not be used.

provisions.title: Section 131
provisions.content:
131. Operators shall sound warning before starting trains, when
trains approach crossings or other trains on adjacent tracks and where
vision is obscured.

provisions.title: Section 132
provisions.content:
132. Hand shovels with handpips shall not be used for cleaning,
depositing materials onto, or removing materials from, conveyor belts
or pulleys.

provisions.title: Section 133
provisions.content:
133. Drive belts shall not be shifted while in motion unless the
machines are provided with mechanical shifters.

provisions.title: Section 134
provisions.content:
134-41) Belts, chains, and ropes shall not be guided onto power-
driven moving pulleys, sprockets or dnnns with the hands except on
slow moving equipment especially designed for hand feeding.
        (2) Pulleys of conveyors shall not be cleaned manually while
the conveyor is in motion, except that idlers may so be cleaned
provided that ,adequate precaution is taken to prevent accidents.
       (3) Belt dressing shall not be applied manually while belts
are in motion unless an aerosol-type dressing is used.

provisions.title: Section 135
provisions.content:
135. When the entire length of a conveyor is visible from the
starting switch, the operator shall visually check to make certain that
all persons are in the clear before starting the conveyor. A positive
audible or visible warning system shall be installed on all conveyors
and operated to warn persons that the conveyor will be started.

provisions.title: Section 136
provisions.content:
136. Crossovers shall be provided where it is necessary to cross
conveyors. Moving conveyors shall be cr-~:.led only at designated
crossover points.

provisions.title: Section 137
provisions.content:
137. Railed walkways shall be provided wherever persons are regular-
ly required to walk alongside elevated conveyor belts. Inclined railed
walkways shall be non-skid or pmvided with cleats.

provisions.title: Section 138
provisions.content:
138. Unguarded conveyors with walkways or within six feet of
ground or floor level shall be equipped with emergency stop devices
or stop cords along their full length.

provisions.title: Section 139
provisions.content:
139. EBective automatic backstops or brakes shall be installed on
inclined conveyor drive units to prevent wnveyors from running in-
advertently in reverse, where a hazard to personnel would be cause2

provisions.title: Section 140
provisions.content:
140. No persox1 shall be allowed to ride a power-driven chain, belt,
 or bucket conveyor, unless the wnveyor is specifically designed for
 the transportation of persons.

provisions.title: Section 141
provisions.content:
141. All drive units on conveyors operating in series shall be electric-
 ally interlocked.

provisions.content:
142.-41) Carriers, including loading and unloading mechanisms shall
be inspected each shift; brakes shall be inspected daily; ropes and
supports shall be inspected as recommended by the manufactwrer or
as physical conditions warrant.
          (2) Records of rape maintenance and inspection shall be kept.

provisions.title: Section 144
provisions.content:
144. Track cable connections shall be designed to offer minimum
obstruction to the passage of wheels.

provisions.title: Section 146
provisions.content:
146. Guards, nets or other suitable protection shall be provided
where ropeways pass over buildings, roadways, and walkways, where
such walkways are in regular use.

provisions.title: Section 148
Section 149
provisions.content:
149. Aerial ropeway buckets shall not be overloaded and feed shall
be regulated to prevent spillage.

151, Areas surrounding inflammable liquid storage tanks, liquefied
fuel gas tanks, explosives magazines, electric substations and trans-
formers shall be kept free from high grass, weeds, underbrush, and
other combustible materials for at least 7 metres (22.97 feet) in all

provisions.content:
154. Unburied inflammable-liquid storage tanks shall be securely
mounted on firm foundations. Outlet piping shall be provided with
flexible connections or other special fittings to prevent adverse effects
from settling.

155.-(1)      In the piping of liquefied petroleum gas-

            approved material.

purposes other than conveying fuel gas shall not be wed.

the building above ground and remain in an above ground and
ventilated location.

156.-31) When the installation of liquefied petroleum gas piping
undergroumd beneath buildings is unavoidable, the piping shall be
encased in a conduit. The conduit shall extend into a normally usable
and accessible portion of the building and, at the point where the
conduit terminates in the building, the space between the conduit
and the gas piping shall be sealed to prevent the possible entrance
of any gas leakage. The conduit shall extend at least 4 inches outside
the building, be vented above grade to the outside and be installed
in a way as to prevent the entrance of water.
          (2) No liquefied petroleum gas pipe smaller than standard 3
 inch iron pipe shall be used in any concealed location.
     THE MlNlNG (SAFETY A N D HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 157
provisions.content:
157. Bends which reduce the internal area or weaken fuel gas
piping or tubing are prohibited.

provisions.title: Section 158
provisions.content:
158. Gas piping in contact with earth or other material which may
corrode the piping, shall be protected against corrosion in an approved
manner. When dissimilar metals are joined underground, an insulating
fitting shall be used. Piping shall not be laid in contact with cinders.

provisions.title: Section 159
provisions.content:
159. Gas piping or tubing shall not be concealed in any location
where corrosive chemicals are used.

provisions.title: Section 160
provisions.content:
160. Gas piping shall not be installed in unfrequented spaces unless
adequate ventilation is provided. Such piping shall be protected against
corrosion.

provisions.title: Section 161
provisions.content:
161. Outdoor gas piping in industrial plant yards installed above
ground shall be securely supported and located where it will be pro-
tected from physical damage.

provisions.title: Section 162
provisions.content:
162. Fuel lines shall be equipped with valves to cut off the fuel
at the source and shall be located and maintained to reduce fire
hazards.

provisions.title: Section 163
provisions.content:
163. All heat sources. including lighting equipment, capable of pro-
ducing combustion shall be insulated or isolated from combustible
materials.

provisions.title: Section 164
provisions.content:
164-41) Before any system of gas piping is put in service, it shall
be carefu~llytested to assure that it is gastight. Where any part of
the system is to be enclosed or concealed, this test should precede
the work of closing in.
        (2) In order to test for tightness, the piping may be filled with
the fuel gas, air, or inert gas, but not with any other gas or liqu-d.
and OXYGEN SHALL NEVER BE USED, and-
    (a) for pipeline only, (between first stage regulator and appliances),
        the piping system must stand a pressure of at least 1.5 bars
        (21.75 p.s.i.) gauge pressure for 25 minutes, without showing
         any drop in pressure, after being stabilized. If any pressure
        drcii, is noted, the location of the leak must be detected by
         using soapy water solution or other approved method of gas
         leak detection. A flame SHALL NEVER be used; and
               mhe inclusion of this page is :uthorized by L.N. 71/1979]
    THE MINING (SAFETY A N D HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977
    (b) when appliances are connected to the piping system, the
        system must stand a pressure of not less than 500 millimetres
        (19.69 inches) water column for at least 10 minutes without
        showing any drop in pressure.

provisions.title: Section 165
provisions.content:
165. Tanks, piping, and fittings shall be examined and tested at
intervals while in service to ensure they are safe, and in particular-
    (a) lines shall be tested as specified in regulation 164 once in
           every twelve months;
    (b) tanks shall be pressure tested once in every five years at 14
        times the safe working pressure; and
    (c) records of all tests and repairs shall be kept.

provisions.title: Section 166
provisions.content:
166. Fawlty lines, tanks and other liquefied petroleum gas equip-
ment shall not be used and gas supplies shall be cut off until faults
have been corrected.

provisions.title: Section 167
provisions.content:
167. Power wires and cables shall be adequately insulated where
they pass through doors or walls or where they present a fire hazard.

provisions.title: Section 168
provisions.content:
168. Abandoned electrical circuits shall be deenergised and isolated
so that they cannot become energised inadvertently.

provisions.title: Section 169
provisions.content:
169. Materials, such as oily waste and rags, whkh are subect to
spontaneous combustion shall be placed in tightly covered metal con-
tainers until disposed of properly.

provisions.title: Section 170
provisions.content:
170.-(1) Solvents with flash points lower than 100Â°F. (38Â°C.)shall
not be used for cleaning.
         (2) Solvents shall not be used near pn open flame or other
ignition source, or near any source of heat, or in an atmosphere that
can elevate the temperature of the solvent above the flash point.

provisions.title: Section 171
provisions.content:
171.-41) Drip pans shall be provided to catch leakage or spillage
when oil or flammable liquids are dispensed in a place or manner
which may create drips or leakage.
           (2) Floors around drip pans shall be kept free from inflammable
liquids.

provisions.title: Section 172
provisions.content:
172.-(1)    Oxygen cylinders shall not be stored near oil or grease.
                 mhe inclusion of this page is authori-ed by L.N. 71119791
     THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977
         (2) Gauges and regulators used with oxygen or acetylene
cylinders shall be kept clean and free of oil and grease.   ,

provisions.title: Section 174
provisions.content:
174. Internal combustion engines, except diesels, shall be shut off
and stopped before being fuelled.

provisions.title: Section 175
provisions.content:
175. Each area shall be provided with suitable fire-fighting equip-
ment adequate for the size of the area and the classes of fire possible.

provisions.title: Section 176
provisions.content:
176.-(1) Buildings or rooms in which oil, grease, inflammable liquids
or other inflammable materials are stored shall be of fire resistant
construction and well ventilated.
        (2) Means shall be provided to confine, remove, control, or
drain away spilled or flowing inflammable liquids.

provisions.title: Section 177
provisions.content:
177. Firefighting equipment which is provided on the mine property
shall be strategically located, readily accessible, plainly marked, pro-
perly maintained, and inspected periodically. Records shall be kept
of such inspections.

provisions.title: Section 178
Section 179
provisions.content:
179. Fire hydrants shall be of a standard type. Adapters shall be
provided to fit the hose equipment of local fire departments. Wrenches
or keys to open the valves shall be readily available.

provisions.title: Section 180
provisions.content:
180. Water pipes, valves. outlets, hydrants, and hoses designated
 for fire fighting purposes shall be inspected every three months and
 tested annually. Records shall be kept of such inspections and tests.
                I l h e inclusion of thls page iB npthori-ed by L.N.71119791
     THE MINING (SAFETY A N D HEALTH) REGULATIONS. 1977

provisions.title: Section 181
provisions.content:
181. Suitable fire extinguishers shall be provided on self-propelled
mobile equipment with enclosed cabs.

provisions.title: Section 182
provisions.content:
182. When welding or cutting near combustible materials, suitable
precautions shall be taken to ensure that smoldering metal or sparks
do not result in a fire. Fire extinguishing equipment shall be readily
available at the site.

provisions.title: Section 183
provisions.content:
183. Instructions for the use of firefighting equipment shall be pro-
minently displayed on or near to such equipment.

provisions.title: Section 184
provisions.content:
184.-(1) A firefighting organization shall be established, equipped,
and trained in firefighting; drills shall be held at least twice a year.
        (2) All employees shall be instructed on current escape and
evacuation plans, fire alarm signals, and applicable procedures to be
followed in case of fire.

provisions.title: Section 185
provisions.content:
185. Valves on oxygen and acetylene tanks shall be kept closed
when the contents are not being used.

provisions.title: Section 186
provisions.content:
186. Belt-conveyors in locations where fire would create a hazard
shall be provided with safety switches to stop the drive pulley automati-
cally in the event of excessive slippage.

provisions.title: Section 187
provisions.content:
187. Fire alarm systems shall be provided and maintained in operating
condition, or adequate fire alarm procedures shall be established to
warn promptly all persons endangered by a fire.

provisions.title: Section 188
provisions.content:
188. At least two independent exits shall be provided where men
work or congregate in enclosed areas.

provisions.title: Section 189
provisions.content:
189. Each mine or plant shall develop standard operating procedures
for fire and other emergencies. Drills shall be held at least once per
year.
                PARTVI. Mining and Ground Control

provisions.title: Section 190
provisions.content:
190.-41) Mining methods shall be consistent with prudent engineer-
ing practices and shall ensure pit wall and bank stability and safe
working conditions.
         (2) Loose lmconsolidated material shall be stripped, for a safe
distance, but in no case less than 10 feet from the top of pit walls.
               [The inclusion of Lhis page is authorized by L.N. 711 19791
    THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 191
provisions.content:
191. The width and height of benches shall be governed by the type
of equipment to be used, the material to be mined and the operation
to be performed.

provisions.title: Section 192
provisions.content:
192. Safe means for scaling pit banks shall be provided. Hazardous
banks shall be scaled before other work is performed in the hazardous
bank area.

provisions.title: Section 193
provisions.content:
193. Men shall not work near or under dangerous banks. Over.
hanging banks shall be taken down immediately, and other unsafe
ground conditions shall be corrected promptly, or the areas shall be
barricaded and posted.

provisions.title: Section 194
provisions.content:
194. Men shall approach from above loose rock and areas to be
scaled and shall scale from a safe location.

provisions.title: Section 195
provisions.content:
195. Banks, benches and sloping terrain shall be examined after
every rain and unsafe .conditions corrected before men work in such
areas.

provisions.title: Section 196
provisions.content:
196. Before a boulder is drilled or manually broken it shall be
moved to a safe location or positioned securely and prevented from
rolling and moving.

provisions.title: Section 197
provisions.content:
197.--(1) Unauthorized persons shall neither enter nor remain in the
operating zone of mobile equipment while these are in operation.
        (2) The operators of such equipment shall not begin or continue
to operate while unauthorized persons are within the equipment's zone
of operation.

provisions.title: Section 198
provisions.content:
198. Clean-up or other operations involving men and mobile equip-
ment working complementarily shall be so conducted that the manual
and mechanical steps run alternately.

provisions.title: Section 199
provisions.content:
199. Men working on grizzlies shall stand on suitable solid footing
or be protected by suitable safety devices.

provisions.title: Section 200
provisions.content:
200. Wherever it is unavoidable to leave mined-out pit walls over
five feet in vertical height and over 30" in slope. such walls shall be
fenced or barricaded to prevent animals or persons falling over them.
              Fhe fnclusion of this pfiso is authorized by L.N. 71119791
     THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977
                             PARTVII. Electricity
  2 0 1 4 1 ) Circuits shall be protected against excessive overloads by
fuses or circuit breakers of the correct type and capacity.
        (2) Electric equipment and circuits shall be provided with
switches or other controls. Such switches or controls shall be of
approved design and construction and shall be properly installed,.

provisions.title: Section 202
provisions.content:
202. Individual overload protection or short-circuit protection shall
be provided for the trailing cables of mobile equipment.

provisions.title: Section 203
provisions.content:
203. Power wires and cables shall have adequate current-carrying
capacity and shall be protected from mechanical injury.

provisions.title: Section 204
provisions.content:
204.+1) Areas containing major electrical installations shall be en-
closed or securely fenced.
          (2) Suitable danger signs shall be posted at all major electrical
installations.
        (3) Areas containing major electrical installations shall be
entered only by authorized persons.

provisions.title: Section 205
provisions.content:
205. Metal fencing and metal buildings enclosing transformers and
switchgear shall be grounded.

provisions.title: Section 206
provisions.content:
206. Power wires and cables shall be insulated adequately where
they pass into or out of electrical compartments, or where they are
installed in buildings and work areas.

provisions.title: Section 208
provisions.content:
208.+1) Telephone and low-potential electric signal wires shall be
protected from contacting energized powerlines, and shall not ba run
in the same conduit or trucking compartment as medim Qr high
voltage wiring.
         (2) High-potential transmission cables shall be cowred, insub
ated, or placed according to acceptable electrical co&s to prevent
contact with low-potential circuits.

provisions.title: Section 209
provisions.content:
209. Electrical connections and resistor grids &at are &Bkdt or
impractical to insulate shall be guarded, unless protection is provided
by location.
                                                                                .
                [The inclusion of chi\ page is - h a l e d   by L.N. 71119791
    T H E MINING (SAFETY A N D HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 210
provisions.content:
210. All metal enclosing or encasing electrical circuits shall be
grounded or provided with equivalent protection. ,

provisions.title: Section 212
provisions.content:
212. Guy wires of poles supporting high-potential conductors shall
be equipped with insulators installed near the pole end.

provisions.title: Section 213
provisions.content:
213.-(1) Electrical equipment shall be de-energized before work
is done on such equipment. Switches shall be locked out or other
measures taken which shall prevent the equipment from being energized
without the knowledge of the individuals working on it.
         (2) Such locks, or preventative devices shall be removed only
by the persons who installed them or by authorized personnel with the
concurrence of the individuals who installed them. If this is not
practical, then authorized personnel may remove the devices after a
thorough check of the job.
       (3) In cases where more than one group are working on the
same equipment, eacb group shall install its own device.

provisions.title: Section 214
provisions.content:
214.+1) Power circuits shall be de-energized before work is done
on such circuits unless hot-line tods are used. Suitable warning signs
shall be posted by the individuals who are to do the work.
        (2) Switches shall be locked out or other measures taken
which shall prevent the power circuits from being energized without
the knowledge of the individuals working on them. Such locks, signs.
or preventative devices shall be removed only by the person who install-
ed them or by authorized personnel.

provisions.title: Section 215
provisions.content:
215. When a potentially dangerous condition is found it shall be
 corrected before electrical equipment or wiring is energized.

provisions.title: Section 216
provisions.content:
216. Principal power switches shall be labelled to show which units
 they control, unless identification can be made readily by locatioa
               me inclusion of thia pass is authorixd by L.N. 71/1979]
     THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 217
provisions.content:
217. At least 1 metre (3.28 feet) of clearance shall be provided
around all parts of stationary electric equipment or switchgear where
access or travel is necessary.

provisions.title: Section 218
provisions.content:
218. Dry wooden platforms, insulating mats, or other electrically
nonconductive material shall be kept in place at all switchboards and
power-control switches where shock hazards exist. However, metal
plates on which a person normally would stand and which are kept
at the same potential as the grounded, metal, non-current-carrying parts
of the power switches to be operated may be used.

provisions.title: Section 219
provisions.content:
219. Electrical motors, switches and controls exposed to damaging
dust or water shall be of dust-tight or water-tight construction.

provisions.title: Section 220
provisions.content:
220. Inspection and cover plates on electrical equipment shall be
kept in place at all times except during testing or repairs.

provisions.title: Section 221
provisions.content:
221.-(1) Hand-held electric tods shall not be operated above 4151
240 volts three phaselsingle phase.
         (2) Hand-held power tools, other than rock drills shall be
equipped with controls requiring constant hand or finger pressure to
operate the tools or shall be equipped with friction or other equivalent
safety devices.
  2 2 2 4 1 ) Fuses shall not be removed or replaced by hand in an
energized circuit, and they shall not otherwise be removed or replaced
in an energized circuit unless equipment and techniques especially
designed to prevent electrical shock are provided and used for such
purpose.
       (2) Fuse tongs or hotline tools shall be used when fuses are
removed or replaced in high-potential circuits.

provisions.title: Section 223
provisions.content:
223. Telegraph, telephone, or signal wires shall not be installed on
the same crossarm with power conductors. When carried on poles
supporting powerlines, they shall be installed below powerlines.

provisions.title: Section 224
provisions.content:
224. Operating controls shall be installed so that they can be operated
without danger of contact with energized conductors.

provisions.title: Section 225
provisions.content:
225. switches and starting boxes shall be of safe design and capacity.
                                              ---                           -
     THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977                         79

provisions.title: Section 226
provisions.content:
226.-41) Every electric motor shall be controlled by an efficient
switch or switches for starting and stopping, so placed as to be easily
operated by the person in charge of the motor and machinery connected
thereto.
         (2) In every place in which any machine is being driven by
an electric motor there shall be means adjacent to the equipment for
switching off the motor or for stopping the machine.

provisions.title: Section 227
provisions.content:
227. Every flexible cable for portable electrical apparatus shall be
connected to the electrical system by a properly constructed connector.

provisions.title: Section 228
provisions.content:
228.-(1) The metal work of all electrical apparatus shall be efficiently
earthed; and any flexible metallic covering of the conductors shall be
itself efficiently earthed and shall.not be the only earth connection for
the metal of the apparatus.
        (2) The lampholder of a portable lamp shall be efficiently
earthed and shall not be in metallic contact with the guard or other
metal work.

provisions.title: Section 229
provisions.content:
229. Portable apparatus and its flexible supply cable shall be con-
trolled by an efficient device suitably located and capable of W n g
off the power.

provisions.title: Section 230
provisions.content:
230.-41) All electrical conductors and apparatus exposed to the
weather, moisture, corrosion, inflammable surroundings or explosive
atmosphere, or used in any process or for any special pucpose shall
be so constructed or proteoted as to prevent danger to life or limb
from shock, bum, or injury to workers or from fire, and such special
precautions shall be taken in the use of such conductors or 3pparatlus
as may be necessary in view of such exposure.
        (2) In particular all eleotrical equipment installed in a location
where the atmosphere is likely ;to become inflammable or explosive
shall be of flame-proof or explosion-proof construction.

provisions.title: Section 231
provisions.content:
231. At the working platform of every switchboard and in every
switohboard passage-way if there are bare electrical conductors exposed
or arranged to be e~posedwhen live so that they may be touohed,
there shdl be a clear and unobstructed passage of adequate and safe
width and height with a firm and even floor. Adequate and safe
means of access shall be provided for every switchboard passageway.
               me inclusion of tbh page b authorized by L.N. 71/1979]
     THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS. 1977

provisions.title: Section 232
provisions.content:
232.-(1) In every plant in which electrical energy is generated or
transformed or is used for any purpose other than lighting an adequate
number of posters giving instructions for the treatment of persons
suffering from electric shock shall be conspicuously exhibited in locations
where such instructions can be easily read by persons employed in
the plant.
         (2) Each employee shall be instructed in, at least one method
of rescue.

provisions.title: Section 233
provisions.content:
233. Proper and effective precautions shall be taken either by ground-
ing or other means to prevent any material other than a condwtor
from becoming electrically charged.

provisions.title: Section 234
provisions.content:
234. Ground continuity conductors shall be provided between the
main switoh-gear and the consuming apparatus.

provisions.title: Section 235
provisions.content:
235. Internal electrical wiring shall be arranged in an orderly manner.
Make-shift connections or wiring shall not be used.

provisions.title: Section 236
provisions.content:
236. Long hand tools or equipment capable of making contact shall
not be used beneath bare overhead conductors or in a room where such
conductors are installed, unless such tools are non-conductive.

provisions.title: Section 237
provisions.content:
237. Outstanding warning signs shall be posted where bare power
lines are installed for overhead manes, cages or other equipment.

provisions.title: Section 238
provisions.content:
238. In each switch room or switch area a schematic diagram of
 the switchboard and all related switchgear shall be readily available
 to authorized personnel.

provisions.title: Section 239
provisions.content:
239. Fire alarm circuits shall not in any circumstances be housed in
 the same condui~tas any other circuit. Where fire alarm circuits and
 other circuits are contained in a common channel or trucking, they
 shall be separated by a continuous portion of fire redstant material.

provisions.title: Section 240
provisions.content:
240. All electrical wiring and installations shall be done in accordance
 with appropriate national or international d e s as approved by the
 Chief Electrical Inspector.
                            PARTVIII. Accessways

provisions.title: Section 241
provisions.content:
241. Safe means of access shall be provided and maintained to all
 working places.
                r h e inclusion of this page is authorized by L.N. 71119791
    THE MlNING (SAFETY A N D HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 242
provisions.content:
242. Crossovers, elevated walkways, elevated ramps, and stairways
shall be of substantial construction, provided with handrails, and
maintained in good condition. Where necessary, toeboards shall be
provided.

provisions.title: Section 243
provisions.content:
243.--(I) Ladders shall be of substantial construction and main-
tained in good condition. Wooden members shall not be painted.
         (2) Portable straight ladders shall be provided with non-slip
bases, shall be placed agai,nst a safe backing and set on secure footing.
        (3) Fixed ladders shall be anchored securely and installed to
provide at least 150,000 millimetres (5.90 inches) of toe clearance.
         (4) Fixed ladders shall project at least 1.0 metre (3.28 feet)
above landings, or substantial handholds shall be provided above the
landings.
        (5) Fixed ladders shall be offset and have substantial railed
landings at least every 6.00 metres (19.68 feet) unless backguards or
other anti-fall devices are attached.
        (6) Steep fixed ladders (70" to 90" from the horizontal) 6.00
metres (19.68 feet) or more in length shall be provided with back-
guards, cages or equivalent protection starting at a point not more
than 2.00 metres (6.56 feet) from the bottom of the ladder.

provisions.title: Section 244
provisions.content:
244. Travelways steeper than 30" from the horizontal shall be pro-
vided with ladders or stairways.

provisions.title: Section 245
provisions.content:
245. Ladderways, stairways, walkways, and ramps shall be kept free
d loose rock and extraneous materials.

provisions.title: Section 246
provisions.content:
246. Men climbing or descending ladders shall face the ladders and
have both hands ftee for climbing.

provisions.title: Section 247
provisions.content:
247. No permanent structures (including backguards), shall be less
than 600.00 millimetres (23.62 inches) from the face or climbing side
of a ladder.

provisions.title: Section 248
provisions.content:
248. Scaffolds and working platforms shall be of substantial con-
struotion and maintained in good condition. Floor boards shall be
laid properly and the scaffolds and working platform shall not be
overloaded.
               IThe inclusion of thir page is authorized by L.N. 71119791
     THE MINING (SAFETY A N D IIEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 249
provisions.content:
249. Floor planks, boards, or plates on a scaffold or working plat-
form shall not be separated by more than 50.00 millimetres (1.97
inches).

provisions.title: Section 250
provisions.content:
250.-(1) Every scaffold, working platform or raised floor from
which a person is liable to fall a distance of more than 2.00 metres
(6.56 feet) shhrll be equipped with guardrails and toeboards of adequate
strength.
         (2) Guardrails shall be to a height of not less than 1.00 metre
(3.28 feet) and toeboards to a height of not less than 100.00 millimetres
(3.94 inches). Vertical separation between rails shall not exceed 750.00
millimetres (29.53 inches).

provisions.title: Section 251
provisions.content:
251. Every working platform, raised floor or scaffold from which
a person is liable to fall a distance of more than 2.00 metres (6.56
feet) shall provide a footing with an unobstructed and free width of
not less than 635 rnillimetres (25 inches).

provisions.title: Section 253
provisions.content:
253. Slippery walkways shall be provided with cleats and handrails
and,/or ropes.

provisions.title: Section 254
provisions.content:
254. Openings above, below or near travelways through which or
into which men or materials may fall shall be protected by railings.
barriers or covers. Where it is impractical to install such protective
devices, adequate warning signals shall be installed.

provisions.title: Section 255
provisions.content:
255.-(1) Carriageways shall be of a construction and width to
comfortably accommodate the movement of traffic lllpon them, and in
particular the width of haulageways shall, where practicable, be a least
three times the width of the widest vehicles in use.
          (2) Where it is impracticable to construot roadways of a
width three times the width of the widest vehicles in use, for example
within tunnels, traffic controllers shall1 regulate the movement of
vehicles.

provisions.title: Section 256
provisions.content:
256. Where a raised pipeline or other obstruction aosses an access-
way, suitable crossovers shall be provided.
               [The inclusion of this p3ge is authorid by L.N. 71119791
    THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULA'TIONS, 1977
                            PARTIX. Guarding

provisions.title: Section 257
provisions.content:
257. Gears, sprockets, chains, drive, head, tail, and takeup pulleys,
flywheels, couplings, shafts, sawblades, fan inlets, and similar exposed
moving machine parts which may be contaoted by persons, and which
may cause injury to persons shall be guarded.

provisions.title: Section 258
provisions.content:
258. Every part of electric generators, motors and rotary converters,
and every flywheel d i r d y connected thereto, shall be securely fenced.
unless it is in such a position or of such a construction as to be as
safe to every person as it would be if securely fenced.

provisions.title: Section 259
provisions.content:
259. No driving belt when not in use shall be allowed to rest or ride
upon a revolving shaft which forms part of the transmission machinery.

provisions.title: Section 260
provisions.content:
260. Projecting set-screws, bolts or keys on any revolving shaft,
spindle, wheel or pinion shall be securely guarded, cut ofT or counter-
sunk.

provisions.title: Section 261
provisions.content:
261. Every tixed vessel, structure, s m p , trench, shaft or pit of which
the edge is l e s than 1 metre (39.37 inches) above the adjoining
ground or platform shall, if it contains any scalding, c o d v e or
poisonous liquid, either be securely covered or be securely fenced to
at least that height, or where by reason of the nature of the work
neither secure covering nor secure fencing to that height is practicable,
d l practicable steps shall be taken by covering, fencing or other means
to prevent any person from falling into the vessel, structure, sump.
trench, shaft or pit.

provisions.title: Section 262
Section 263
provisions.content:
263. Grinding wheels shall be operated within the specifications of
the manufacturer of the wheels.

provisions.title: Section 264
provisions.content:
264. Fork-lift trucks, front-end loaders, bulldozers and other heavy
mobile equipment shall be provided with substantial canopies where
overhead protection is necessary.
    THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 265
provisions.content:
265. Guards shall be-
    (a) securely in place while machinery is being operated;
    (b) sufficiently strong, of adequate form and dimensions; and

302. Every hoist or lift shall be securely fenced and in particular-

303.-41) No hoist or lift shall be used for carrying persons unless
it is provided with a cage, which is-

     (b) fitted on each side with a gate from which access is provided
         to a landing place, with efficient interlocking or other devices

         cage is at a landing place, and that the cage cannot be moved

307. The operating mechanism of the clutch of every hoist drum
shall be provided with a locking mechanism, or interlocked electridy

clutch.

316. Only experienced operators shall operate hoists, cranes and
draglines except where new personnel are being trained.

319.-(1) Jacks shall be so constructed that they will not continue
to lift when overloaded.

failure destroys or interferes with its jacking ability.
             PARTXII. Materials Storage and Handling

provisions.title: Section 320
provisions.content:
320.-(1) Materials shall (be stored and stacked in a manner which
minimizes stumbling or fall-of-material hazards.
         (2) Materials that can create hazards if accidentally liberated
from their containers shall be stored in a manner that minimizes the
dangers.
         (3) Hazardous materials shall be stored in containers of a type
approved for such use by recognized agencies; suoh containers shall
be labelled appropriately.

provisions.title: Section 321
provisions.content:
321.--(I) Portable compressed and liquefied gas cylinders shall be
secured in a safe manner and so as to prevent any discharge of the
liquid phase.
        (2) Valves on compressed gas cylinders shall be protected by
covers when being transported or stored and installed in a safe location
when the cylinders are in use.

provisions.title: Section 322
provisions.content:
322. Taglines shall be attached to suspended materid that requires
 steadying or guidance, wherever this is practicable.

provisions.title: Section 324
provisions.content:
324. Materials shall not be dropped from an elevation unless the
 drop area is guarded or sufEcient warning is given.
               TIhe inclusion of this vage is authorized by L.N. 71119791

provisions.title: Section 325
provisions.content:
325. Men shall not ride on loads being moved by cranes or derricks.
nor shall they ride the hoisting hooks.

provisions.title: Section 326
provisions.content:
326. Substances that react violently or liberate dangerous fumes
when mixed shall be stored in such a manner that they cannot come
in contact with each other.

provisions.title: Section 327
provisions.content:
327.41) Only men wearing protedive equipment shall stand near
pots or ladles when ,molten material is being handled; warning shall
be given before a pour is made or the pot is moved.
         (2) Only men wearing suitable protective equipment shall
attend to the loading and offloading of acids, alkalis or other corrosive
substances.

provisions.title: Section 328
provisions.content:
328. Operator-carrying overhead cranes shall be provided with-
    (a) bumpers at each end of each rail;
    (b) limit switches to halt uptravel of the blocks before they strike
        the hoist:
    (c) effective audible warning signals under the control of the
         operator;
    (4 a means to lockout the disconnect switoh.

provisions.title: Section 329
provisions.content:
329. No person shall work from or travel on the bridge of an over
head crane unless the bridge is provided with substantial footwalks
with toeboards and railings the length of the bridge.

provisions.title: Section 330
provisions.content:
330. Forklift trucks shall be moved with the load in a low position
and shall descend ramps with the load behind.

provisions.title: Section 331
provisions.content:
331.41) Only bolted, screwed or equivalent connections shall be
used on acid and caustic lines, when carrying out loading, offloading
or related operations.
         (2) No air pressures higher than 2 bars (29 p.s.i.g.) shall be
used in the offloading of acids or alkalis. Vessels and lines employing
air pressure for liquid transfers shall be constructed, equipped, main-
tained and handled as pressure vessels.

provisions.title: Section 332
provisions.content:
332. Controls for the offloading of corrosive liquids under pressure
shall be located at a safe distance but within view of the operations.

Systems for such offloading shall be approved by the Commissioner
of Mines.

provisions.title: Section 333
provisions.content:
333.41) Vessels and lines with their connections shall be brought
to atmospheric pressure and all corrosive fluids bled off before such
vessels and lines are opened or taken apart in maintenance operations.
Drains and valves shall be correctly positioned to facilitate compliance
with this regulation.
         (2) Valves, couplings and other connections on acid or caustic
lines shall be opened gradually. Bolts shall not be competely removed
before joint seals are broken.

provisions.title: Section 334
provisions.content:
334. In shops or rooms in which mechanical handling equipment is
used, and where persons are expected to walk, sufficient safe clearances
shall be allowed for aisles. Aisles shall be kept clear of obstructions.

provisions.title: Section 335
provisions.content:
335. All places of employment, passageways, storerooms, and service
rooms shall be kept clean and orderly and in a sanitary condition. The
floor of every workroom shall be maintained in a clean and, so far as
possible. a dry condition. Where wet processes are used, drainage shall
be maintained, and false floors, platforms, mats or other dry standing
places shall be provided where practicable.

provisions.title: Section 336
provisions.content:
336. All active areas shall be provided with effective drainage systems.
               PARTXIII. Air Quality and Ventilation

provisions.title: Section 337
provisions.content:
337.41) The exposure of a person in a mine or plant to airborne
contaminants shall not exceed the threshold limit values, calculated
on the basis of a time-weighted average, as specified in the Third %hid.
Schedule.
         (2) Where for any reason a person is exposed to limits in
excess of those specified in the aforesaid Schedule--
    (a) in the case of contaminants other than those designated with
        a "C" in the Schedule, the limit of exposure shall not be
         of a greater magnitude than the Commissioner may from time
        to time deem to be permissible; and
     (b) in tbe case of contaminants designated with a "(2" in the
         Scheduli, such person shall be wifidrawn from such area
         immediately upon detection of the excess concentration of the
         contaminant.
               IThe inclusion of this page is authorized by L.N. 71119791
     THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977

provisions.title: Section 338
provisions.content:
338. Dust, gas, mist, and fume surveys shall be oonducted as frequently
as necessary to determine the adequacy of control measures.

provisions.title: Section 339
provisions.content:
339. Muckpiles, haulage roads, rock transfer points, crushers and
other points where dust is produced in amounts sufficient to cause a
health or safety hazard shall be wetted down as often as necessary,
unless the dust is controlled adequately by other methods.

provisions.title: Section 340
provisions.content:
340. Respirators shall not be substituted for environmental control
measures. However, where environmental oontrols have not been
developed or when necessary by nature of the work involved (for
example, welding, sand blasting, lead burning), a person may work
for reasonable periods of time in concentrations of airborne contamin-
ants which exceed ceiling "C" limits or the limit of permissible
excursions, if such person wears a respiratory protective device approved
by the Commissioner as protection against the particular hazards
involved.

provisions.title: Section 341
provisions.content:
341. Atmospheres in all active areas shall contain at least 20 percent
oxygen by dry volume.

provisions.title: Section 342
provisions.content:
342.--(I) Wherever radiation is used in diagnostic, analytic or other
operations, no employee shall be permitted an exposure to more
than the equivalent of 5.000 millirem in any consecutive 12-month
period nor the equivalent of 3.000 millirem in any consecutive 3-month
period. The maximum accumulated doses shall not exceed 5 (N-18)
rem for any employee, where N is the employee's age in years.
       (2) Rooms or areas in which radiation is generated shall be
posted with identifying precautionary signs. Personal dosimeters or
other methods shall continually monitor radiation exposure levels.

provisions.title: Section 343
provisions.content:
343. Effeotive provision shah be made for securing and maintaining
a reasonable temperature in each workroom, but no method shall be
employed which results in the escape into the air of any workroom
of any fume of such a oharaoter and to such an extent as to be
likely to be injurious or offensive to persons employed therein.

provisions.title: Section 344
provisions.content:
344. Illumination sufficient for safe working conditions, and complying
 with standards approved by the Commissioner shall be provided in
 all work areas and accessways. Standby artificial lighting, independent
 of the principal power generating system, shall be provided in power

provisions.title: Section 345
provisions.content:
345.-41) All persons shall wear suitable hard hats when in or around
a mine or plant where a hazard exists that could cause injury to
unprotected heads.
         (2) All persons shall wear suitable protective footwear when
in or around a mine or plant where a hazard exists that could cause
injury to unprotected feet.
         (3) All persons shall wear safety glasses, goggles, or face
shields or other suitable protective devices when in or around an area
of a mine or plant where a hazard exists which could cause injury to
unprotected eyes.

provisions.title: Section 346
provisions.content:
346. Safety belts and lines shall be worn when men work where
there is danger of falling; a second person shall tend the lifeline when
bins, tanks or other dangerous areas are entered.

provisions.title: Section 347
provisions.content:
347. Protective clothing, rubber gloves and goggles or face-shields
shall be worn by persons handling substances that are corrosive, toxic,
or injurious to the skin.

provisions.title: Section 348
provisions.content:
348. Protective clothing or equipment and face-shields or goggles
shall be worn when welding, cutting. or working with molten metal.

provisions.title: Section 350
provisions.content:
350. Protective gloves shall be worn by employees handling materials
which may cause injury, provided that gloves shall not be worn where
they could create a hazard by becoming entwined or caught in moving
parts of machinery.

provisions.title: Section 351
provisions.content:
351. Finger rings should not be worn while working in or around
 a mine or plant.

provisions.title: Section 352
provisions.content:
352. Seat belts shall )be provided in all vehicles with cabs or roll
 proteotion.

provisions.title: Section 353
provisions.content:
353.--(I) No employee shall be permitted an expsure to noise in
 excess of that specified in the table of Permissible Noise Exposures Third
                                                                      Schedule.
 given in the Third Schedule.
         (2) Noise level measurements shall be made using a sound
 level meter or dosimeter approved by the Commissioner. No exposure
100              THE MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977
            shall exceed 115 d~ for continuous noise or 140 d~ peak sound pressure
            level for impact noises.

provisions.title: Section 354
provisions.content:
354. Where it is otherwise impracticable to reduce exposure to within
            permissible levels, approved protective equipment shall be provided
            and used to reduce exposure to within the permissible levels.

provisions.title: Section 355
provisions.content:
355. Life jackets or belts shall be worn where there is danger from
            falling into water.

provisions.title: Section 356
provisions.content:
356. Personal protective devices shall be of adequate quality and
            form to provide the required protection.

provisions.title: Section 357
provisions.content:
357. Adequate first aid materials, including stretchers and blankets,
            shall be provided at places convenient to all working areas. h t e r or
            neutralizing agents shall be available where corrosive chemicals or other
            harmful substances are stored, handled, or used and in particular-
                (a) first aid stations shall be equipped with first aid boxes marked
                    with the words "Fint Aid" 'and containing at least all the
First
                    equipment prescribed in the First Schedule;
Schedule.
                (b) each first aid box shall be placed under the charge of a
                    responsible person who shall hold a first aid certificate and
                    shall always be readily available during working hours. A
                    notice stating the name of the person in charge shall be
                    posted at the mine or plant:
                (c) selected supervisors and security men shall be trained in first
                     aid and if possible, one out of every ten of the persons em-
                     ployed shall be trained in emergency first aid treatment;
                (d) where the total number of persons employed in any one shift
                    exceeds one hundred there shall be provided and maintained
                    in good order a suitable first aid room;
                (e) the first aid room shall be used for first aid and ambulance
                     work. It shall be situated within a central location and shall
                     have a floor space of not less than one hundred square feet
                     a d shall be adequately lighted and kept clean. It shall be
                     distinguished by the words "First Aid", "Medical Centre" or
                     "Clinic" conspicuously posted;

    (f) the first aid room shall be adequately equipped and shall
        contain at least all the equipment prescribed in the Second
        Schedule;                                                        Second
                                                                         Schedule.
    (g) the first aid room shall be placed under the charge of a
        competent person or persons appointed in writing by the
        responsible officer. A person shall not be appointed unless
        he is a qualified nurse or doctor or the holder of a certificate
         of proficiency in first aid, from a society or body approved
        by the Commissioner.

provisions.title: Section 358
provisions.content:
358. The person or persons in charge of the first aid room shall
always be readily available during working hours and shall keep a
record of all cases treated at the first aid room, showing-
    (a) the name of the person treated;
    (b) the time and date of treatment;
    (c) 'the nature of the injury or illness; and
    (4 the name of the person by whom the treatment was given.

provisions.title: Section 359
provisions.content:
359. At every mine or plant, the employer shall, for the purpose
of the removal of patients in serious cases of accidents or sickness,
provide and maintain in good condition a suitably constructed ambulance
carriage, unless arrangements have been made by or on behalf of the
employer either to obtain such a carriage promptly, when required,
from a hospital or other place within a reasonable distance from the
mine, or to provide such a carriage jointly with the owners of other
mines or plants in the neighbourhood.

provisions.title: Section 360
provisions.content:
360. The employer or some other qualified person appointed by him
in writing shall h p e c t , at intervals not exceeding six months, the
accommodation, equipment and material provided at the mine or plmt
and the working of the organization at the mine or plant for first
aid and ambulance work; and if on such inspection anything is found
to be defective or lacking, it shall be remedied without delay. Records
of such inspections shall be kept.

provisions.title: Section 361
provisions.content:
361. Persons about to be regularly employed in a mine or plant
shall be medically examined and employees shall be subjeot to further
medical examinations annually if over 40 years in age and biennially
if under 40.

provisions.title: Section 362
provisions.content:
362. There shall not be in attendance for work in any mine or plant
                  any person known to be sdering from an infectious disease as defined
Cap. 320          in the Public Health Law.
(1953 Edition).

provisions.title: Section 363
provisions.content:
363. In places wheie caustic, acid or other corrosive substanw a;e
                  stored, piped, handled or used, properly functioning safety showers
                  and eye wash fountains shall be available on each floor or level. Safety
                  showers and eye wash fountains shall be of such numbers and locations
                  as are adequate for emergency use.

provisions.title: Section 364
provisions.content:
364. Every plant shall be kept in a clean state, and free from effluvia
                  arising from any drain or sanitary convenience, and without prejudice
                  to the generality of the foregoing provision-
                      (a) suitable covered receptacles shall be provided in the plant
                          for the disposal of d i and
                                                   ~ refuse;
                      (b) accumulations of dirt and refuse shall be removed daily from
                          the floors and benches of workrooms, and from the staircases
                          and passages;
                       (c) the floor of every workroom shall be cleaned at least once
                           in every week by washing or if it is effective and suitable, by
                           sweeping or other method;
                       (6) all inside walls and partitims, and all ceilings or ]tops of
                           rooms, and all walls, sides and tops of passages and staircases
                           shall be kept clean.

provisions.title: Section 365
provisions.content:
365. An enclosed area shall not, while work is carried on, be so over-
                  crowded as to cause risk or injury to the health of the persons employed
                  therein, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing pro-
                  visions-
                       (a) an area shall be deemed to be overcrowded, as aforesaid, if
                           the number of persons employed at a time in any workroom
                           is suoh that the amount of cubic space allowed for every
                           person employed in the room is less than 12 cubic metres
                           (423.78 cubic feet);
                       (b) in -calculating, for the purpose of this provision the amount
                           of cubic space in any room, no space more than 4 metres
                           (13.12 feet) above the floor shall be taken into account and,
                           where a room contains a gallery, the gallery shall be treated
                            for the purposes of this provision as if it were partitioned

         off from the remainder of the room and formed a separate
         room.

provisions.title: Section 366
provisions.content:
366. Sufficient and suitable sanitary conveniences for the persons
employed shall be provided, maintained and kept clean and the following
requirements shall have effect-
    (a) in cases where females are employed there shall be at least
         one suitable sanitary convenience for every 25 females;
    (b) in cases where males are employed there shall be at least one
         suitable sanitary convenience (not being a convenience suitable
         merely as a urinal), for every 25 males;
    (c) in cases where the number of males employed exceed 100 and
         sufficient urinal accommodation is also provided, it shall be
         suÂ£licient if there is one such convenience as aforesaid for
         every 25 males up to the first 100, and one for every 50
         thereafter;
     (d) in calculating the number of conveniences any number of
         persons less than 25 or 50, as the case may be, shall be
         reckoned as 25 or 50;
     (e) every sanitary convenience shall be sufficiently ventilated and
         no sanitary convenience shall communicate-
            (i) with any workroom; or
           (ii) with any enclosed space which also commumicates with
                any workroom unless such space is adequately ventil-
                ated.

provisions.title: Section 367
provisions.content:
367. An adequate supply of wholesome drinking water shall be
provided at points conveniently accessible to all persons employed.

provisions.title: Section 368
provisions.content:
368.-41) There shall be provided and maintained for the use of
employed persons adequate and suitable facilities for changing of
clothing and for accommodating clothing not worn during working
hours.
        (2) Separate accommodation shall be provided for persons of
each sex and shall, when so required by the Commissioner, include
adequate shower bath facilities.

provisions.title: Section 369
provisions.content:
369. There shall be provided and maintained for the use of employees
a suitable and adequate lunch-room. which shall be furnished with-

    (a) sufficient tables and chairs or. other suitable seating accommoda-
         tion; and
    (b) adequate means, including hot water, for the washing of dishes.
     PART XV. Additional Provisions for Underground Working
  In addition to all other applicable regulations the following provisions
shall apply to underground workings :

provisions.title: Section 370
provisions.content:
370.-(1) Men working underground shall examine and test the back.
face and ribs of their working places at the beginning of each shift
and frequently thereafter.
          (2) Supervisors shall examine the ground conditions daily to
ensure that proper testing and ground con~trol practices are being
followed.
          (3) Loose ground shall be taken down or effectively supported
before any other work is done. Ground conditions along haulageways
and travelways shall be examined daily and scaled or sapported as
necessary.

provisions.title: Section 371
provisions.content:
371. An adequate supply of approved ,timber or rock bolts shall be
provided and used where necessary to prevent danger to any person
from a fall or dislodgement of earth, rock or other material forming
the back, face or ribs of any underground working tunnel or shaft.

provisions.title: Section 372
provisions.content:
372. No timbering or other support for any part of an excavation
shaft, earthwork or tunnel shall be erected or be substantially added
to, altered or dismantled except under the direction of a competent
person and so far as possible by competent workmen possessing adequate
experience of such work. All material for any such work shall be
inspected by a competent person on each occasion before being taken
into use and material found defective in any respect shall not be used.

provisions.title: Section 373
provisions.content:
373. Approved monitoring devices shall be installed to monitor
ground stresses and movement underground.

provisions.title: Section 374
provisions.content:
374. Where at any time there is reasonable cause to apprehend that
any underground working has approached within 40 metres (43.75 yards)
of a place which may contain an accumulation of water or other liquid
matter or noxious gas, adequate and timely precautions shall be taken
and, in particular, the working shall not be more than 2.5 metres
(8.2 feet) in width or 2.5 metres (8.2 feet) in height and there shall
be constantly kept at least one borehole, not less than 3 metres (9.84
feet) in igneous rock or 5 metres (16.4 feet) in other strata, in advance
o?the face of the said working, and sufficient flank, roof and floor bore-
     THr MINING (SAFETY AND HEALTH) REGULATIONS, 1977
holes of similar lengths as may be necessary to ensure that the water
or other liquid matter or gas shall bz tapped in the first instance by a
borehole.

provisions.title: Section 375
provisions.content:
375. No internal combustion engine shall be used in any underground
mines, tunnels or workings unless a permit to use equipment with
such engines has first been obtained from the Commissioner. The
conditions and restrictions in any such permit shall be complied with
and a permit to we internal combustion engines underground may
be revoked for failure to comply with the conditions and restrictions
of the permit.

provisions.title: Section 376
provisions.content:
376. The quantity of fresh air circulated through each underground
working place shall be at least 6 cubic metres (211.89 cubic feet) per
minute for each person, provided that where this quantity of air is           .
not provided naturally or where this quantity is insufficient to prevent
harmful accumulations of dust, fumes, vapours, or gases, enough
additional fresh air shall be provided by mechanical means.

provisions.title: Section 377
provisions.content:
377. Where in underground workings it is not practicable to provide
sufficient illumination in all areas, individual cap lamps shall be worn:
  Provided that standby lighting shall be on hand where individual cap
lamps are not used.

provisions.title: Section 378
provisions.content:
378. At every shaft in which injured persons are raised or lowered
and where the cage is not large enough to permit a stretcher being
laid flat, and at every shaft where persons are raised or lowered
otherwise than in a cage, there shall be provided and used a suitable
jacket or attachment to minimize discomfort and prevent aggravation
of an injury.
